isis.stitle: DT/DTI-466 A and B Series DT/DTI/DTA-466 C Diesel Engine Diagnostics (1993) - ENGINE DIAGNOSTIC TEST PROCEDURES - DT/DTI/DTA - 466 C SERIES DIESEL ENGINES - SHUTOFF CABLE/ELECTRIC SHUTOFF DT/DTI/DTA-466 C Engines (With Robert Bosch "MW" or "A" Fuel Injection Pump) - III. EXTERNALLY SWITCHED ELECTRIC SHUTOFF (AUTOMATIC SHUTOFF) - 1989 M0DEL YEAR AND BEYOND

svcproc.title: III. EXTERNALLY SWITCHED ELECTRIC SHUTOFF (AUTOMATIC SHUTOFF) - 1989 M0DEL YEAR AND BEYOND
svcproc.para: PROBLEM: ENGINE WILL CRANK, BUT WILL NOT START.

entry.para: Prior to ESO Solenoid diagnostic check, verify that the proper COLD START procedure has been followed.
1. Set the parking brake, put the transmission in neutral and depress the clutch if applicable. DO NOT DEPRESS THE ACCELERATOR PEDAL AT THIS TIME!
2. Turn the keyswitch to the "ON" position.
3. Turn the keyswitch to the "START" position to engage the starter and crank the engine.
4. After the starter in engaged fully, depress the accelerator pedal to provide starting fuel quantity.
5. Refer to vehicle Operator's Manual for additional starting instructions.
6. If the engine still DOES NOT START begine ESO diagnostic routine.

caution.para: PLACE THE TRANSMISSION IN NEUTRAL WITH THE PARKING BRAKE ON.

important.para: VERIFY THE ELECTRIC SHUTOFF IS INOPERABLE AS FOLLOWS: VISUALLY OBSERVE THE SHUTOFF LEVER (FIGURES 6.24 & 6.25) AND TURN THE KEY SWITCH TO THE "START"or "RUN"* POSITION. THE SHUTOFF LEVER SHOULD ROTATE COUNTERCLOCKWISE (CCW) AS THE SOLENOID PLUNGER "PULLS IN". IF THIS DOES NOT OCCUR TURN THE KEY SWITCH TO THE "ON" or "RUN"* POSITION. DEPRESS THE PLUNGER, BY HAND, AND OBSERVE IF THE PLUNGER REMAINS "PULLED IN". IF NOT, DETERMINE THE CAUSE AND CORRECT AS FOLLOWS:

step1.para: Fuse - Inspect the electric shutoff fuse. If burned out, replace.

12 Volt Supply - This externally switched solenoid design incorporates a "pull" coil and a "hold" coil which are activated by separate circuits. There are three terminals in the Metri-Pack connector. The wires and the connector of the solenoid are labled to indicate "common", "pull" or "hold". [Refer to Figure 6.26].

svcproc.para: The "pull" coil is wired into the cranking motor circuit. Check for 12 volts between the "common" and "pull" terminals of the solenoid mating connector with the key switch in the "start" position [cranking engine].

note.para: The minimum voltage required for the solenoid to pull in is 9 volts.

svcproc.para: The "hold" coil is wired into the key switch. Check for 12 volts between the "common" and "hold" terminals of the solenoid mating connector while the key switch is in the "on" position. The minimum voltage for the solenoid to remain "pulled in" [Fully Depressed] is 9 volts.

caution.para: DO NOT "JUMP" OR BYPASS THE FUSE.

svcproc.para: If voltage available to the solenoid is under 12V DC, check battery condition, wiring, connections, key switch and electric shutoff relay (if applicable).

step1.para: Rubber Boot - The rubber boot seals the core from dirt and moisture.

svcproc.para: Verify that the boot is firmly attached to the sole noid body.
Replace any solenoid which has a torn boot.
Replace the solenoid if the boot becomes hard and inflexible in cold temperatures (-10 °F or be low). This condition may hinder "pull-in" of the solenoid.

figure.caption: Figure 6.24 Externally Switched Electric Shutoff Solenoid w/"MW" Pump Shown
Figure 6.25 Externally Switched Electric Shutoff Solenoid w/"A" Pump Shown

note.para: The boot should be free of paint. Paint will cause the boot to become soft and catch between the spring and plunger. This will prevent the plunger from seating properly. The boot should also have a small breather hole in the second pleat from the base of the solenoid.

step1.para: Inspect for evidence of dust, dirt, brass powder, or blackened deposits on the plunger or in the solenoid core.

note.para: If evidence of a worn solenoid is found, as described above, solenoid condition is marginal and may not "pull in" quickly or consistently.

step1.para: Measure resistance (ohms) across the terminals of the solenoid as follows: (Refer to Figure 6.26).

svcproc.para: Be sure the key switch is off. Disconnect the power supply to the solenoid. Connect an ohm meter to the "Pull and Common" terminals (Figure 6.26).
.16 to .23 ohms resistance should be observed.
Connect an Ohm meter to the "Hold" and "Common" terminals (Figure 6.26).
11.6 to 16.5 ohms resistance should be observed.
